utterances: Duff Badgley is the Green Party candidate for governor.
He gets around the campaign trail taking only public transportation, pulling his things behind him in a roller bag.
His big issue is global warming, and he doesn't like what he sees on the streets of Seattle.
I see cars, cars, cars, cars, cars.
I see death machines.
That's how I refer to cars: death machines.
In a traditional system, Badgley's name would be on the November ballot, and he'd have the whole fall to get out there with his environmental message.
But with the new top-two system, he's almost certain to be knocked out now, in August, effectively ending his campaign early.
It will take from me the bully pulpit, which is a vital way for me to get out the word.
The access to press: You wouldn't be talking to me now if I weren't a Green Party candidate for governor.
Other small parties are also unhappy.
Scott Lindsley, chairman of the Washington state Libertarians, says the new primary system has discouraged members of his party from running.
In 2004, we had 49 partisan candidates in Washington state.
This year, we have four.

So many people who wanted to run felt like this was a race like you're running the Boston Marathon, and they're going to tell you halfway through that, sorry, because you're not in the top two, we're not going to let you go on and finish the race.
Lindsley says if the new primary was meant to increase voter choice, well, then, it's backfired.
For example, he said, there are parts of Seattle where races will likely be narrowed down to two Democrats.
That menas on the November ballot, there will be just one party represented.
But that's a good thing, says the man who helped to design the system.
David Olson says in areas where one party is that strong, the new primary forces entrenched incumbents to face upstarts from their own party in the general election.
Still, Olson does sympathize with the small parties' broader complaint.
I'm the first to acknowledge: Third parties are going to be discriminated against by this system.
But Olson says the only way to fix that discrimination would be a more radical change in the rules, something like proportional representation or maybe even a move toward a parliamentary system.
And he very much doubts that that will happen anytime soon.
Martin Kaste, NPR News, Seattle.

That's Osama bin Laden, or at least that's what the forensic analysts at the FBI audio lab here in Quantico have concluded.
In fact, any time one of those video or audio tapes pops up on al Jazeera, these are the people asked to make sure it's real.
Steven Lanser heads up the team.
Sometimes we deal with recordings that are broadcast over the air, and sometimes there are collections that the FBI has made or law enforcement has made in a variety of different ways.
Like wiretaps.
Wiretaps, for example, or body recorders that sources would use.
Here's an interesting tidbit.
It doesn't matter what language you're speaking.
When you say anything your voice follows a particular pattern, and this FBI audio program recognizes that and can match up one voice with another, whether it's speaking Arabic or Urdu or English.

We use an automated system, and that automated system looks at a variety of different voice features that it extracts automatically and give us a confidence score of the speaker versus the unknown speaker.
Lanser pulls up the next example on the computer.
Okay, can you hear me?
Okay, very well, yourself?
Great.
Saved as in - oh, you're talking about eternity.
Now compare that voice in English with this one in Arabic.
(Speaking foreign language)
To me, the voices sounded the same.
I couldn't say identical necessarily, but very much the same.
And in the old days of the FBI, that's exactly how they did voice comparisons, using agents who had a pretty good ear, a skill they called critical listening, or oral comparison.
I personally can't do that but some of the people here can tell by listening if it likely is or is not the same person.
I would say that the system that we're using here gives us a lot better confidence of the identification of the speaker.
Lanser says the FASR system's science is still imperfect.
By itself, a match on FASR isn't enough to convict anyone.
But added to other pieces of evidence, it could provide intelligence to either include or eliminate a suspect.
This new world of audio forensics helps with more traditional crime fighting too.
(Soundbite of gunshots)
That's the sound of gunfire.
And gunshot detection systems are the next frontier in audio forensics.
Cities across the country are starting to put noise sensors on building rooftops or other locations to pinpoint gunshots.
Basically the system analyzes the time it takes for the sound of gunfire to travel to various sensors; then using GPS, the system creates a picture of where the gun went off.
It can provide that information to police within seconds.
(Soundbite of gunshots)
Quick.
How many shots?
I don't know.
And that's a good illustration to show you that, you know, we would use what we call a high resolution wave form to visually look at that and determine how many shots.
That's another interesting thing about gunshots.
No matter how hard you try, your brain isn't wired in a way that can completely process them.
That's because it's tough for the brain to remember high-impulse sounds accurately.
Technology can help.
Lanser turns to a computer screen in the lab.

As you can see on the screen here, we have a wave form, and from that we can probably determine how many shots, but just from listening to it, it would be difficult for me even to make that determination.
Audio technology is helping some cities fill in these gaps where the brain falls short.
Minneapolis police chief Tim Dolan has used the technology in two high-crime areas for several years now.
In a recent case, Dolan said a 16-year-old girl was caught in some gang-related crossfire.
The suspects claim the officers fired the first shots.

We were able to tell from the ShotSpotter exactly how many shots were fired first and be able to break down, you know, who shot when, how many shots, and then also how many shots exactly that were fired by both the officers and this individual.
So it made a big difference.
It was able to take away an alibi from the people that were involved in that shooting.
The technology can provide a street address for where the shots were fired, but if there is more than one shot, it can actually determine which direction the person firing the shots was going.
While Dolan says the system has been helpful in Minnesota, the technology isn't perfect.
In the beginning, there were false alarms.
Here in Minnesota, I mean even ice popping, there's a - can be a huge crack.
Or you know, roofing guns and those type of things.
And so you will get some of those, but by and large officers are trusting the dispatches that come from the ShotSpotter.
Dolan says Minneapolis has started coordinating its ShotSpotter gun detection systems with cameras.
He expects that will be the next step in this technology.
We're getting fewer false positives and it's getting better.
And so what's out there today is much better than what was out there three years ago, and I would guess that technology-wise with the improvements it's going to get better, you know, every year.
The FBI says that whether it is recognizing the voices of possible terrorists or reconstructing a shooting, new audio forensics are proving to be invaluable in investigations.
Local law enforcement appears to agree.
More than 20 American cities have already installed new gunshot detection systems.
Dina Temple-Raston, NPR News.
